title: 2010 Russian wildfires
desc: Severe heatwave-induced wildfires in Russia.

title: Black Saturday bushfires (2009)
desc: Deadliest bushfires in Australia's history.

title: 1988 Yellowstone fires
desc: Extensive fires in Yellowstone National Park.

title: Great Fire of 1910 (Big Burn)
desc: Large wildfire in Idaho and Montana.

title: Ensisheim meteorite (1492)
desc: Oldest recorded meteorite fall in Europe.

title: Murchison meteorite (1969)
desc: Carbonaceous chondrite rich in organics.

title: Tagish Lake meteorite (2000)
desc: Fall over Tagish Lake, British Columbia/Yukon.

title: Sutter's Mill meteorite (2012)
desc: CM chondrite fell over California.

title: Peekskill meteorite (1992)
desc: Fireball that struck a parked car in Peekskill, NY.

title: Park Forest meteorite (2003)
desc: Meteorite shower over Illinois.

title: Winchcombe meteorite (2021)
desc: First UK carbonaceous chondrite recovered promptly.

title: Carancas impact event (2007)
desc: Small crater and illnesses after meteorite impact.

title: Benld meteorite (1938)
desc: Meteorite crashed through a garage in Illinois.

title: Orgueil meteorite (1864)
desc: CI chondrite that fell in southern France.

title: Omagh bombing (1998)
desc: Real IRA car bombing in Northern Ireland.

title: Tissint meteorite (2011)
desc: Martian meteorite fall in Morocco.

title: Punic Wars (264-146 BC)
desc: Series of wars between Rome and Carthage.
desc_long: The Punic Wars were three wars fought between Rome and Carthage, ultimately resulting in the destruction of Carthage and Roman dominance in the Mediterranean.

title: Third Crusade (1189-1192)
desc: Crusade to recapture Jerusalem from Saladin.
desc_long: Led by Richard the Lionheart, Philip II of France, and Frederick Barbarossa, this crusade attempted to reconquer the Holy Land.

title: Hussite Wars (1419-1434)
desc: Religious wars in Bohemia following Jan Hus's execution.
desc_long: A series of religious wars in Bohemia against Catholic crusaders, pioneering early gunpowder warfare tactics.

title: War of Spanish Succession (1701-1714)
desc: European conflict over Spanish throne.
desc_long: Major European conflict that involved most of the major European powers and resulted in the Treaty of Utrecht.

title: Great Northern War (1700-1721)
desc: Coalition war against Swedish Empire.
desc_long: Russia, Denmark-Norway, and Saxony-Poland fought against the Swedish Empire, ending Swedish supremacy in the Baltic.

title: War of Austrian Succession (1740-1748)
desc: Conflict over Maria Theresa's succession.
desc_long: Major European conflict triggered by the disputed succession of Maria Theresa to the Habsburg lands.

title: Taiping Rebellion (1850-1864)
desc: Massive civil war in Qing China, 20-30 million deaths.
desc_long: One of the deadliest conflicts in history, this civil war was led by Hong Xiuquan who claimed to be Jesus's brother.

title: Russo-Turkish War (1877-1878)
desc: War that led to Bulgarian independence.
desc_long: Russia's victory against the Ottoman Empire led to the independence of several Balkan states.

title: Boxer Rebellion (1899-1901)
desc: Anti-foreign, anti-colonial uprising in China.
desc_long: A violent anti-foreign and anti-Christian uprising that took place in China, suppressed by an eight-nation alliance.

title: Italo-Turkish War (1911-1912)
desc: Italy's conquest of Ottoman Libya.
desc_long: First war where airplanes were used for reconnaissance and bombing, resulting in Italian control of Libya.

title: First Balkan War (1912-1913)
desc: Balkan League against Ottoman Empire.
desc_long: The Balkan League defeated the Ottoman Empire, significantly reducing Ottoman territory in Europe.

title: Greco-Turkish War (1919-1922)
desc: War between Greece and Turkish nationalists.
desc_long: Fought between Greece and Turkish nationalist forces, ending with Greek defeat and population exchanges.

title: Chaco War (1932-1935)
desc: Bloodiest South American war of 20th century.
desc_long: Fought between Bolivia and Paraguay over the Gran Chaco region, one of South America's deadliest wars.

title: Winter War (1939-1940)
desc: Soviet invasion of Finland.
desc_long: Despite being vastly outnumbered, Finland mounted fierce resistance against Soviet invasion during extreme winter conditions.

title: First Indochina War (1946-1954)
desc: French colonial war in Vietnam.
desc_long: Anti-colonial war between French forces and Vietnamese independence movement, ending with French defeat at Dien Bien Phu.

title: Suez Crisis (1956)
desc: British-French-Israeli invasion of Egypt.
desc_long: Military conflict following Egypt's nationalization of the Suez Canal, marking the end of British and French colonial power.

title: Six-Day War (1967)
desc: Israel vs Arab neighbors, major territorial changes.
desc_long: Brief but decisive war where Israel captured the Sinai, Golan Heights, West Bank, and Gaza Strip.

title: Yom Kippur War (1973)
desc: Egypt and Syria surprise attack on Israel.
desc_long: Coordinated attack by Egypt and Syria on Israel during Yom Kippur, leading to eventual Israeli victory.

title: Ogaden War (1977-1978)
desc: Somalia vs Ethiopia over Ogaden region.
desc_long: Conflict between Somalia and Ethiopia over the disputed Ogaden region, with Soviet and Cuban involvement.

title: Iran-Iraq War (1980-1988)
desc: 8-year war between Iran and Iraq, 1 million deaths.
desc_long: One of the longest conventional wars of the 20th century, involving trench warfare and chemical weapons.

title: Falklands War (1982)
desc: Argentina vs UK over Falkland Islands.
desc_long: 10-week war between Argentina and United Kingdom over disputed Falkland Islands in South Atlantic.

title: Gulf War (1990-1991)
desc: Coalition forces liberate Kuwait from Iraq.
desc_long: US-led coalition expelled Iraqi forces from Kuwait after Iraqi invasion, showcasing modern military technology.

title: Yugoslav Wars (1991-2001)
desc: Series of ethnic conflicts during Yugoslavia's breakup.
desc_long: Complex series of ethnic wars during the dissolution of Yugoslavia, involving genocide, ethnic cleansing, and war crimes.

title: First Chechen War (1994-1996)
desc: Chechnya's war for independence from Russia.
desc_long: Brutal conflict between Russian Federation and Chechen Republic, resulting in de facto Chechen independence.

title: Eritrean-Ethiopian War (1998-2000)
desc: Border war between Eritrea and Ethiopia.
desc_long: Costly border conflict between two African nations, resulting in tens of thousands of casualties.

title: Second Congo War (1998-2003)
desc: Africa's deadliest conflict, 5.4 million deaths.
desc_long: Often called 'Africa's World War,' involving nine nations and numerous armed groups, deadliest war since WWII.

title: Iraq War (2003-2011)
desc: US-led invasion and occupation of Iraq.
desc_long: Controversial invasion that overthrew Saddam Hussein but led to prolonged insurgency and regional instability.

title: Russo-Georgian War (2008)
desc: Five-day war between Russia and Georgia.
desc_long: Brief but intense war over South Ossetia and Abkhazia, resulting in Russian recognition of their independence.

title: Libyan Civil War (2011)
desc: Uprising that overthrew Gaddafi regime.
desc_long: Armed conflict during Arab Spring that led to NATO intervention and overthrow of Muammar Gaddafi.

title: Syrian Civil War (2011-present)
desc: Ongoing multi-sided conflict in Syria.
desc_long: Complex civil war involving multiple factions, foreign interventions, ISIS, and massive humanitarian crisis.

title: Munich Olympic Massacre (1972)
desc: Palestinian terrorists killed 11 Israeli athletes.
desc_long: Black September organization took Israeli Olympic team members hostage, resulting in deaths of 11 athletes during rescue attempt.

title: Lockerbie Bombing (1988)
desc: Pan Am Flight 103 destroyed over Scotland, 270 deaths.
desc_long: Terrorist bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing all 259 on board and 11 on ground.

title: Air India Flight 182 Bombing (1985)
desc: Bomb destroyed plane off Irish coast, 329 deaths.
desc_long: Sikh extremist bombing of Air India Flight 182, deadliest aviation terrorist attack before 9/11.

title: Tokyo Sarin Attack (1995)
desc: Aum Shinrikyo cult released sarin gas in subway.
desc_long: Deadly chemical attack on Tokyo subway by Aum Shinrikyo cult, killing 13 and injuring thousands.

title: Oklahoma City Bombing (1995)
desc: Domestic terrorism, federal building destroyed, 168 deaths.
desc_long: Timothy McVeigh's truck bomb destroyed Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, deadliest domestic terror attack in US.

title: Khobar Towers Bombing (1996)
desc: Truck bomb at US military housing, 19 deaths.
desc_long: Terrorist attack on US Air Force housing complex in Saudi Arabia, attributed to Hezbollah Al-Hejaz.

title: US Embassy Bombings (1998)
desc: Al-Qaeda bombed US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.
desc_long: Simultaneous truck bomb attacks on US embassies in Dar es Salaam and Nairobi by Al-Qaeda, 224 deaths.

title: USS Cole Bombing (2000)
desc: Al-Qaeda suicide attack on US Navy destroyer.
desc_long: Al-Qaeda operatives detonated small boat alongside USS Cole in Aden harbor, killing 17 sailors.

title: Bali Bombings (2002)
desc: Jemaah Islamiyah nightclub bombings, 202 deaths.
desc_long: Series of terrorist bombings in tourist district of Kuta, Bali, by Islamic militant group Jemaah Islamiyah.

title: Moscow Theater Siege (2002)
desc: Chechen militants took 850 hostages, 170 deaths.
desc_long: Chechen terrorists seized Moscow theater with 850 hostages; Russian forces used gas during rescue, causing many deaths.

title: Madrid Train Bombings (2004)
desc: Coordinated train bombings, 193 deaths.
desc_long: Series of coordinated terrorist bombings against commuter train system, Spain's deadliest terrorist attack.

title: 7/7 London Bombings (2005)
desc: Suicide bombings on London transport, 52 deaths.
desc_long: Four Islamist suicide bombers attacked London's public transport system during morning rush hour.

title: Mumbai Terror Attacks (2008)
desc: Pakistani militants attacked Mumbai, 166 deaths.
desc_long: Series of coordinated terrorist attacks across Mumbai by Laskhar-e-Taiba, including siege of Taj Hotel.

title: Norway Attacks (2011)
desc: Far-right terrorist killed 77 people.
desc_long: Anders Breivik detonated bomb in Oslo then massacred 69 at youth camp on Utøya island.

title: Boston Marathon Bombing (2013)
desc: Pressure cooker bombs at marathon finish line, 3 deaths.
desc_long: Tsarnaev brothers detonated two homemade bombs at Boston Marathon, killing 3 and injuring hundreds.

title: Peshawar School Massacre (2014)
desc: Taliban attacked school, 149 deaths mostly children.
desc_long: Tehrik-i-Taliban terrorists attacked Army Public School in Peshawar, one of deadliest terrorist attacks in Pakistan.

title: Charlie Hebdo Shooting (2015)
desc: Islamist gunmen attacked satirical magazine office.
desc_long: Al-Qaeda gunmen attacked Charlie Hebdo magazine offices in Paris, killing 12, sparking global free speech debate.

title: November Paris Attacks (2015)
desc: ISIS coordinated attacks across Paris, 130 deaths.
desc_long: Series of coordinated ISIS terrorist attacks including Bataclan theater siege, deadliest in France since WWII.

title: Brussels Bombings (2016)
desc: ISIS bombings at airport and metro, 32 deaths.
desc_long: Coordinated ISIS terrorist attacks at Brussels Airport and Maalbeek metro station.

title: Nice Truck Attack (2016)
desc: ISIS-inspired truck attack on Bastille Day, 86 deaths.
desc_long: Terrorist drove truck into Bastille Day crowd on Promenade des Anglais in Nice, France.

title: Rosetta Stone Discovery (1799)
desc: Key to deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphs.
desc_long: French soldiers discovered stone with same text in three scripts, enabling translation of ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs.

title: Pompeii Excavation (1748)
desc: Roman city preserved by volcanic eruption.
desc_long: Systematic excavation began of ancient Roman city buried by Mount Vesuvius eruption in 79 AD.

title: Tutankhamun's Tomb Discovery (1922)
desc: Howard Carter discovered intact pharaoh's tomb.
desc_long: Most complete ancient Egyptian royal tomb ever found, containing thousands of artifacts and famous golden mask.

title: Terracotta Army Discovery (1974)
desc: 8,000 life-sized terracotta warriors found.
desc_long: Farmers discovered burial site with thousands of terracotta soldiers guarding first Chinese Emperor Qin Shi Huang's tomb.

title: Dead Sea Scrolls Discovery (1947)
desc: Ancient Jewish religious manuscripts found.
desc_long: Bedouin shepherds discovered ancient Hebrew manuscripts in Qumran caves, oldest known biblical texts.

title: Lascaux Cave Paintings (1940)
desc: Paleolithic cave art, 17,000 years old.
desc_long: Teenagers discovered cave complex with some of world's most famous prehistoric paintings from Upper Paleolithic.

title: Machu Picchu Rediscovery (1911)
desc: Hiram Bingham revealed Incan citadel to world.
desc_long: American historian brought international attention to 15th-century Inca citadel high in Andes mountains.

title: Sutton Hoo Ship Burial (1939)
desc: Anglo-Saxon royal ship burial discovered.
desc_long: One of most significant archaeological finds in British history, 7th-century Anglo-Saxon burial with spectacular treasures.

title: Altamira Cave Paintings (1879)
desc: Upper Paleolithic cave art discovered.
desc_long: Discovery of prehistoric cave paintings sparked debate about human artistic capabilities in Stone Age.

title: Göbekli Tepe Discovery (1994)
desc: World's oldest known temple, 11,000 years old.
desc_long: Revolutionary discovery of monumental temple complex predating Stonehenge by 6,000 years, challenging theories of civilization.

title: Ötzi the Iceman Discovery (1991)
desc: 5,300-year-old mummy found in Alps.
desc_long: Naturally mummified human from Copper Age found in glacier, providing unprecedented insights into prehistoric life.

title: Nag Hammadi Library (1945)
desc: Early Christian Gnostic texts discovered.
desc_long: Collection of early Christian and Gnostic texts found in sealed jars, including Gospel of Thomas.

title: Cave of the Hands
desc: 9,000-year-old handprints in Patagonian cave.
desc_long: Cave with hundreds of stenciled handprints dating back 9,000 years, important site of prehistoric art.

title: Vindolanda Tablets (1973)
desc: Roman wooden writing tablets at Hadrian's Wall.
desc_long: Oldest surviving handwritten documents in Britain, providing vivid glimpse of Roman military life.

title: Lady of Cao Discovery (2006)
desc: Moche female ruler's tattooed mummy found.
desc_long: Well-preserved mummy of powerful Moche woman revealed female rulers in ancient Peru, challenging previous assumptions.

title: Antikythera Mechanism (1901)
desc: Ancient Greek astronomical calculator recovered.
desc_long: 2,000-year-old analog computer for predicting astronomical positions, most sophisticated mechanism from ancient world.

title: Lucy Fossil Discovery (1974)
desc: 3.2 million-year-old human ancestor found.
desc_long: 40% complete skeleton of Australopithecus afarensis, crucial evidence for human evolution.

title: Chauvet Cave Discovery (1994)
desc: 32,000-year-old cave paintings, oldest known.
desc_long: Contains earliest known and best preserved figurative cave paintings, revolutionizing understanding of prehistoric art.

title: Tomb of Qin Shi Huang (1974)
desc: First Emperor's massive tomb complex.
desc_long: Vast burial complex of China's first emperor, including famous Terracotta Army, still largely unexcavated.

title: Denisovan Discovery (2010)
desc: New extinct human species identified from DNA.
desc_long: Genetic analysis of finger bone revealed previously unknown human species that interbred with modern humans.

title: Sikhote-Alin Meteorite (1947)
desc: Massive iron meteorite shower, largest in modern history.
desc_long: Spectacular daylight meteor fall witnessed by many, creating over 100 craters with total mass of 23 tons recovered.

title: Allende Meteorite (1969)
desc: Carbonaceous chondrite, most studied meteorite.
desc_long: Fell shortly before Apollo 11 moon landing, contains pre-solar grains older than Solar System.

title: Murchison Meteorite (1969)
desc: Contains organic compounds and amino acids.
desc_long: Carbonaceous chondrite containing over 70 amino acids, providing evidence for extraterrestrial organic chemistry.

title: Tagish Lake Meteorite (2000)
desc: Pristine carbonaceous chondrite collected on ice.
desc_long: Rare type of meteorite collected quickly on frozen lake, preserving primitive organic material.

title: Mbale Meteorite Shower (1992)
desc: Meteorite hit boy but caused no injury.
desc_long: Rare witnessed fall where meteorite struck a person (young boy) without causing significant injury.

title: Peekskill Meteorite (1992)
desc: Meteorite hit parked car, widely videotaped.
desc_long: Widely documented meteorite fall that struck parked Chevrolet Malibu, captured on multiple videos.

title: Almahata Sitta Meteorite (2008)
desc: First meteorite tracked in space before impact.
desc_long: Asteroid 2008 TC3 was first detected in space before atmospheric entry, enabling recovery of unusual meteorite fragments.

title: Ensisheim Meteorite (1492)
desc: Oldest meteorite fall with preserved specimen.
desc_long: One of oldest recorded meteorite falls with specimen still preserved, witnessed by many in medieval Europe.

title: Barwell Meteorite (1965)
desc: Largest meteorite to fall in Britain in modern times.
desc_long: Witnessed fall of L6 chondrite over English village, largest meteorite recovery in UK history.

title: Fukang Pallasite (2000)
desc: Stunning pallasite with olivine crystals.
desc_long: One of most beautiful meteorites ever found, containing translucent olivine crystals in iron-nickel matrix.

title: Shaanxi Earthquake (1556)
desc: Deadliest earthquake in history, 830,000 deaths.
desc_long: Estimated magnitude 8.0 earthquake in China's Shaanxi province, deadliest earthquake ever recorded.

title: Valdivia Earthquake (1960)
desc: Most powerful earthquake ever recorded, magnitude 9.5.
desc_long: Great Chilean Earthquake generated tsunamis across Pacific, killing thousands in Chile, Hawaii, Japan, Philippines.

title: Tangshan Earthquake (1976)
desc: Magnitude 7.6, up to 655,000 deaths.
desc_long: One of deadliest earthquakes of 20th century, devastating Chinese industrial city during early morning.

title: Indian Ocean Earthquake (2004)
desc: Magnitude 9.1, triggered devastating tsunami, 230,000 deaths.
desc_long: Third-largest earthquake ever recorded generated massive tsunami affecting 14 countries around Indian Ocean.

title: Kashmir Earthquake (2005)
desc: Magnitude 7.6, 87,000 deaths.
desc_long: Devastating earthquake in Pakistan-administered Kashmir and northern Pakistan, massive destruction in mountainous region.

title: Haiti Earthquake (2010)
desc: Magnitude 7.0, 220,000 deaths, capital devastated.
desc_long: Catastrophic earthquake struck near Port-au-Prince, one of deadliest natural disasters ever recorded.

title: Tōhoku Earthquake & Tsunami (2011)
desc: Magnitude 9.1, tsunami, Fukushima nuclear disaster.
desc_long: Most powerful earthquake in Japan's history triggered massive tsunami and Fukushima nuclear meltdown.

title: Nepal Earthquake (2015)
desc: Magnitude 7.8, 9,000 deaths, historic sites destroyed.
desc_long: Devastating earthquake destroyed many heritage sites in Kathmandu Valley, triggered avalanches on Mount Everest.

title: Lisbon Earthquake (1755)
desc: Great earthquake, tsunami, fires destroyed Lisbon.
desc_long: One of deadliest earthquakes in history, followed by tsunami and fires, profoundly influenced European philosophy.

title: Turkey-Syria Earthquakes (2023)
desc: Magnitude 7.8 and 7.5, over 59,000 deaths.
desc_long: Catastrophic earthquake doublet struck southern Turkey and northern Syria, one of deadliest earthquakes of 21st century.

title: Titanic Sinking (1912)
desc: RMS Titanic struck iceberg, 1,500 deaths.
desc_long: 'Unsinkable' luxury liner sank on maiden voyage after hitting iceberg, one of deadliest peacetime maritime disasters.

title: Hindenburg Disaster (1937)
desc: German airship caught fire while landing, 36 deaths.
desc_long: Hydrogen-filled airship burst into flames while landing in New Jersey, ending airship era, captured on film and radio.

title: Bhopal Gas Tragedy (1984)
desc: Chemical plant leak, worst industrial disaster, 16,000+ deaths.
desc_long: Methyl isocyanate gas leak from Union Carbide plant, deadliest industrial accident in history.

title: Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster (1986)
desc: Nuclear reactor explosion, worst nuclear accident.
desc_long: Catastrophic nuclear accident during safety test, releasing massive radiation, creating exclusion zone still uninhabitable.

title: Tenerife Airport Disaster (1977)
desc: Two Boeing 747s collided on runway, 583 deaths.
desc_long: Deadliest aviation accident in history: KLM and Pan Am jumbo jets collided in fog on Tenerife runway.

title: Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill (2010)
desc: BP oil rig explosion, worst marine oil spill.
desc_long: Explosion and sinking of oil platform caused largest marine oil spill in history, devastating Gulf of Mexico ecosystem.

title: Costa Concordia Disaster (2012)
desc: Cruise ship capsized off Italian coast, 32 deaths.
desc_long: Luxury cruise ship struck reef and capsized near Giglio Island, captain abandoned ship before evacuation complete.

title: Rana Plaza Collapse (2013)
desc: Garment factory building collapse, 1,134 deaths.
desc_long: Deadliest structural failure in modern history, eight-story building housing garment factories collapsed in Bangladesh.

title: Fukushima Nuclear Disaster (2011)
desc: Nuclear meltdowns after earthquake and tsunami.
desc_long: Tsunami damaged cooling systems at nuclear plant causing three reactor meltdowns, worst nuclear accident since Chernobyl.

title: Aberfan Disaster (1966)
desc: Coal waste avalanche buried school, 144 deaths.
desc_long: Colliery spoil tip collapsed onto Welsh village, engulfing school and houses, killing 116 children and 28 adults.

title: Punic Wars (264-146 BC)
desc: Rome vs Carthage for Mediterranean dominance.
desc_long: Three wars between Rome and Carthage, including Hannibal's famous crossing of the Alps.

title: Battle of Gaugamela (331 BC)
desc: Alexander defeats Persian Empire.
desc_long: Decisive victory of Alexander the Great over Darius III, leading to the fall of the Persian Empire.

title: Spartacus Revolt (73-71 BC)
desc: Major slave uprising against Rome.
desc_long: Third Servile War led by gladiator Spartacus, one of history's most famous slave rebellions.

title: Battle of Thermopylae (480 BC)
desc: 300 Spartans vs Persian army.
desc_long: Legendary last stand of King Leonidas and 300 Spartans against the massive Persian invasion force.

title: Battle of Cannae (216 BC)
desc: Hannibal's greatest victory over Rome.
desc_long: Hannibal's brilliant tactical victory, encircling and destroying a much larger Roman army.

title: Construction of Colosseum (70-80 CE)
desc: Rome's greatest amphitheater built.
desc_long: The Flavian Amphitheatre, seating 50,000, became the symbol of Roman engineering and entertainment.

title: Eruption of Mount Vesuvius (79 CE)
desc: Destroyed Pompeii and Herculaneum.
desc_long: Catastrophic volcanic eruption buried Roman cities in ash, preserving them for archaeology.

title: Library of Alexandria Founded (300 BC)
desc: Greatest library of ancient world.
desc_long: Center of scholarship and learning in the Hellenistic world, housing hundreds of thousands of scrolls.

title: Qin Dynasty Unifies China (221 BC)
desc: First unified Chinese empire established.
desc_long: Qin Shi Huang unified warring states, standardized writing, currency, and began the Great Wall.

title: Mauryan Empire Peak (250 BC)
desc: Ashoka's reign, Buddhism spread.
desc_long: Emperor Ashoka's conversion to Buddhism and spread of dharma across Asia.

title: Roman Republic Founded (509 BC)
desc: Rome transitions from monarchy to republic.
desc_long: The overthrow of the last king established the Roman Republic and its system of consuls and senate.

title: Persian Empire Founded (550 BC)
desc: Cyrus the Great establishes empire.
desc_long: Cyrus the Great founded the Achaemenid Empire, which became the largest empire of ancient times.

title: Parthenon Completed (432 BC)
desc: Temple to Athena on Acropolis finished.
desc_long: The magnificent temple symbolizing ancient Greek civilization and architectural achievement.

title: Death of Socrates (399 BC)
desc: Philosopher executed by Athens.
desc_long: Socrates sentenced to death by drinking hemlock, martyrdom for philosophical inquiry.

title: Han Dynasty Established (206 BC)
desc: Golden age of Chinese civilization begins.
desc_long: The Han Dynasty ushered in a period of prosperity, expansion, and cultural development in China.

title: Battle of Adrianople (378 CE)
desc: Goths defeat Roman Empire.
desc_long: Devastating Roman defeat marking the beginning of the end for the Western Roman Empire.

title: Edict of Milan (313 CE)
desc: Christianity legalized in Roman Empire.
desc_long: Constantine's decree granting religious tolerance, transforming Christianity from persecuted sect to dominant religion.

title: Council of Nicaea (325 CE)
desc: First ecumenical council defines Christianity.
desc_long: Emperor Constantine convened bishops to establish orthodox Christian doctrine and the Nicene Creed.

title: Fall of Western Roman Empire (476 CE)
desc: Last Western Roman Emperor deposed.
desc_long: Romulus Augustulus overthrown by Odoacer, marking the end of ancient Rome and beginning of the Middle Ages.

title: Founding of Constantinople (330 CE)
desc: New capital of Roman Empire established.
desc_long: Constantine founded the city that would become the capital of the Byzantine Empire for over 1000 years.

title: Crucifixion of Jesus (33 CE)
desc: Execution of Jesus Christ in Jerusalem.
desc_long: The crucifixion and reported resurrection of Jesus became the foundation of Christianity.

title: Assassination of Julius Caesar (44 BC)
desc: Roman dictator murdered in Senate.
desc_long: Julius Caesar assassinated by senators on the Ides of March, plunging Rome into civil war.

title: Great Fire of Rome (64 CE)
desc: Devastating fire destroys much of Rome.
desc_long: Fire burned for six days, destroying 10 of 14 districts. Nero blamed Christians, beginning persecutions.

title: First Jewish-Roman War (66-73 CE)
desc: Jewish revolt against Roman rule.
desc_long: Major rebellion ended with destruction of Second Temple and siege of Masada.

title: Antonine Plague (165-180 CE)
desc: Pandemic devastates Roman Empire.
desc_long: Likely smallpox or measles killed 5 million, weakening Roman military and economy.

title: Crisis of the Third Century (235-284 CE)
desc: Rome nearly collapses into chaos.
desc_long: Period of civil wars, invasions, plague, and economic crisis nearly destroyed the Roman Empire.

title: Battle of Salamis (480 BC)
desc: Greek naval victory over Persians.
desc_long: Decisive naval battle where outnumbered Greeks defeated the Persian fleet, turning point in Persian Wars.

title: Peloponnesian War (431-404 BC)
desc: Athens vs Sparta for Greek dominance.
desc_long: Prolonged conflict between Athens and Sparta that reshaped ancient Greece and weakened city-states.

title: Plague of Athens (430 BC)
desc: Epidemic kills quarter of Athenian population.
desc_long: Mysterious disease devastated Athens during Peloponnesian War, killing Pericles and weakening the city.

title: Alexander's Conquests (334-323 BC)
desc: Macedonian empire spans three continents.
desc_long: Alexander the Great conquered from Greece to India, spreading Hellenistic culture across the known world.

title: Burning of Persepolis (330 BC)
desc: Alexander destroys Persian capital.
desc_long: Alexander the Great burned the ceremonial capital of the Persian Empire, symbolizing the end of Achaemenid rule.

title: Wars of the Diadochi (322-281 BC)
desc: Alexander's generals fight for empire.
desc_long: Succession wars after Alexander's death divided his empire into Hellenistic kingdoms.

title: Imperial Crisis (235-284 CE)
desc: Over 50 emperors in 50 years.
desc_long: Period of extreme instability with rapid succession of emperors, invasions, and economic collapse.

title: Diocletian's Reforms (284 CE)
desc: Roman Empire restructured and stabilized.
desc_long: Diocletian established the Tetrarchy and reformed administration, temporarily saving the empire.

title: Battle of Tours (732 CE)
desc: Franks halt Muslim expansion into Europe.
desc_long: Charles Martel's victory stopped the Umayyad advance into Western Europe, shaping European history.

title: Charlemagne Crowned Emperor (800 CE)
desc: Revival of Western Empire.
desc_long: Pope Leo III crowned Charlemagne Emperor, establishing the Holy Roman Empire and Carolingian Renaissance.

title: Viking Age Begins (793 CE)
desc: Lindisfarne monastery raided.
desc_long: Norse raiders attacked Lindisfarne, beginning centuries of Viking expansion across Europe.

title: Baghdad Founded (762 CE)
desc: Abbasid capital becomes center of learning.
desc_long: The Round City of Baghdad became the capital of the Islamic Golden Age, center of science and culture.

title: Treaty of Verdun (843 CE)
desc: Carolingian Empire divided.
desc_long: Division of Charlemagne's empire among his grandsons, shaping modern European borders.

title: East-West Schism (1054 CE)
desc: Christianity splits into Catholic and Orthodox.
desc_long: Formal division between Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox churches that persists to this day.

title: Battle of Hastings (1066 CE)
desc: Norman conquest of England.
desc_long: William the Conqueror defeated King Harold II, transforming English culture and governance.

title: First Crusade Launched (1096 CE)
desc: Christian military expedition to Holy Land.
desc_long: Pope Urban II called for crusade to recapture Jerusalem, beginning centuries of religious warfare.

title: Founding of Cairo (969 CE)
desc: Fatimid Caliphate establishes new capital.
desc_long: Cairo founded as al-Qahira, becoming one of the world's great medieval cities and Islamic centers.

title: Reconquista Begins (722 CE)
desc: Christian reconquest of Iberia starts.
desc_long: Battle of Covadonga marked the beginning of the 800-year Christian reconquest of Spain from Muslim rule.

title: Battle of Manzikert (1071 CE)
desc: Seljuk Turks defeat Byzantine Empire.
desc_long: Decisive Turkish victory opened Anatolia to Turkish settlement and weakened Byzantine power.

title: Angkor Wat Built (1113-1150 CE)
desc: Largest religious monument constructed.
desc_long: Khmer Empire built this massive Hindu-Buddhist temple complex, showcasing peak of their civilization.

title: University of Bologna Founded (1088 CE)
desc: First university in Europe established.
desc_long: The oldest continuously operating university in the world, marking the birth of European higher education.

title: Saladin Retakes Jerusalem (1187 CE)
desc: Muslim forces recapture Holy City.
desc_long: After the Battle of Hattin, Saladin's forces recaptured Jerusalem from the Crusaders.

title: Magna Carta Signed (1215 CE)
desc: Foundation of constitutional law.
desc_long: King John forced to sign charter limiting royal power, establishing principles of rule of law.

title: Mongol Invasion of Rus' (1237-1242 CE)
desc: Mongols conquer Russian principalities.
desc_long: Batu Khan's invasion devastated Kievan Rus', establishing Mongol rule for over 200 years.

title: Black Death Arrives in Europe (1347 CE)
desc: Bubonic plague kills third of Europe.
desc_long: The Black Death pandemic killed 75-200 million people, transforming European society and economy.

title: Battle of Crécy (1346 CE)
desc: English longbows defeat French cavalry.
desc_long: Revolutionary English victory demonstrating the power of longbowmen over traditional knights.

title: Fall of Constantinople (1453 CE)
desc: Ottoman Turks conquer Byzantine capital.
desc_long: Mehmed II conquered Constantinople, ending the Byzantine Empire and medieval era.

title: Joan of Arc Leads French (1429 CE)
desc: Teenage girl inspires French victories.
desc_long: Joan of Arc lifted the Siege of Orléans and turned the tide of the Hundred Years' War.

title: Gutenberg's Printing Press (1440 CE)
desc: Movable type revolutionizes information.
desc_long: Johannes Gutenberg's printing press enabled mass production of books, transforming European culture.

title: Battle of Agincourt (1415 CE)
desc: Outnumbered English defeat French army.
desc_long: Henry V's legendary victory against vastly superior French forces during Hundred Years' War.

title: Columbus Reaches Americas (1492 CE)
desc: European contact with New World begins.
desc_long: Columbus's voyage initiated permanent contact between Europe and the Americas, changing world history.

title: Vasco da Gama Reaches India (1498 CE)
desc: Sea route to India discovered.
desc_long: Portuguese explorer opened direct maritime trade route between Europe and Asia.

title: Leonardo Paints Mona Lisa (1503 CE)
desc: Masterpiece of Renaissance art created.
desc_long: Leonardo da Vinci created the world's most famous painting, epitomizing Renaissance artistic achievement.

title: Sistine Chapel Ceiling Completed (1512 CE)
desc: Michelangelo's masterpiece finished.
desc_long: After four years of work, Michelangelo completed the iconic ceiling frescoes including The Creation of Adam.

title: Luther's 95 Theses (1517 CE)
desc: Protestant Reformation begins.
desc_long: Martin Luther's challenge to Catholic Church practices sparked the Protestant Reformation.

title: Magellan's Circumnavigation (1519-1522 CE)
desc: First voyage around the world.
desc_long: Magellan's expedition (completed by Elcano) proved Earth's sphericity and opened Pacific to Europeans.

title: Fall of Aztec Empire (1521 CE)
desc: Cortés conquers Tenochtitlan.
desc_long: Spanish conquistador Hernán Cortés defeated the Aztec Empire, ending Mesoamerican independence.

title: Copernicus Heliocentric Theory (1543 CE)
desc: Sun-centered model of solar system proposed.
desc_long: Nicolaus Copernicus published revolutionary theory placing the Sun at the center of the universe.

title: Council of Trent (1545-1563 CE)
desc: Catholic Counter-Reformation begins.
desc_long: Catholic Church's response to Protestant Reformation, defining doctrine and implementing reforms.

title: Battle of Lepanto (1571 CE)
desc: Holy League defeats Ottoman navy.
desc_long: Decisive naval victory halted Ottoman expansion in the Mediterranean, last major galley battle.

title: Spanish Armada Defeated (1588 CE)
desc: England defeats Spanish invasion fleet.
desc_long: English naval victory established Britain as a major sea power and began Spanish decline.

title: Shakespeare Writes Hamlet (1600 CE)
desc: Greatest play in English language created.
desc_long: William Shakespeare's masterpiece defined Renaissance literature and explored universal human themes.

title: Jamestown Colony Founded (1607 CE)
desc: First permanent English settlement in Americas.
desc_long: Establishment of Jamestown marked the beginning of English colonization in North America.

title: Galileo's Telescope Observations (1609 CE)
desc: Astronomical discoveries support Copernicus.
desc_long: Galileo's telescopic observations of moons of Jupiter and phases of Venus revolutionized astronomy.

title: Thirty Years' War Begins (1618 CE)
desc: Religious war devastates Central Europe.
desc_long: One of Europe's most destructive conflicts, killing 8 million people and reshaping European politics.

title: Napoleon Bonaparte Born (1769 CE)
desc: Future emperor of France enters world.
desc_long: Birth of the military genius who would reshape Europe and export Revolutionary ideals.

title: Declaration of Independence (1776 CE)
desc: American colonies declare independence.
desc_long: Thirteen colonies declared freedom from Britain, establishing principles of liberty and democracy.

title: French Revolution Begins (1789 CE)
desc: Monarchy overthrown, republic proclaimed.
desc_long: Storming of the Bastille sparked revolution that transformed France and inspired movements worldwide.

title: Haitian Revolution Begins (1791 CE)
desc: Successful slave rebellion establishes nation.
desc_long: Only successful slave revolt in history, establishing first black republic and second independent nation in Americas.

title: Rosetta Stone Discovered (1799 CE)
desc: Key to deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphs.
desc_long: French soldiers found the stone that enabled scholars to unlock ancient Egyptian writing.

title: Battle of Trafalgar (1805 CE)
desc: Nelson's victory secures British naval supremacy.
desc_long: Admiral Nelson defeated Franco-Spanish fleet, ensuring British control of seas for a century.

title: Battle of Waterloo (1815 CE)
desc: Napoleon's final defeat.
desc_long: Wellington and Blücher defeated Napoleon, ending his Hundred Days and the Napoleonic Wars.

title: Congress of Vienna (1815 CE)
desc: European powers redraw map after Napoleon.
desc_long: Diplomatic conference established balance of power in Europe that lasted until World War I.

title: Bolívar Liberates Colombia (1819 CE)
desc: South American independence movement advances.
desc_long: Simón Bolívar's military campaigns freed much of South America from Spanish colonial rule.

title: Monroe Doctrine (1823 CE)
desc: US opposes European colonialism in Americas.
desc_long: President Monroe declared that European powers should not interfere in Western Hemisphere affairs.

title: First Photograph Taken (1826 CE)
desc: Niépce creates first permanent photo.
desc_long: Joseph Nicéphore Niépce captured the first permanent photograph, revolutionizing visual documentation.

title: Erie Canal Opens (1825 CE)
desc: Major transportation link transforms US economy.
desc_long: 363-mile canal connected Great Lakes to Atlantic, spurring westward expansion and economic growth.

title: Texas Revolution (1836 CE)
desc: Texas gains independence from Mexico.
desc_long: After the Battle of the Alamo and San Jacinto, Texas established itself as independent republic.

title: First Opium War (1839-1842 CE)
desc: Britain forces China to open trade.
desc_long: British victory forced China into unequal treaties, beginning the 'Century of Humiliation.'

title: Irish Potato Famine (1845-1852 CE)
desc: Blight kills million, million emigrate.
desc_long: Potato blight devastated Ireland, causing mass starvation and emigration that shaped Irish history.

title: Revolutions of 1848 (1848 CE)
desc: Liberal uprisings sweep Europe.
desc_long: Wave of revolutionary movements challenged conservative regimes across Europe, though most ultimately failed.

title: California Gold Rush (1849 CE)
desc: Mass migration transforms California.
desc_long: Discovery of gold brought 300,000 people to California, accelerating US westward expansion.

title: Perry Opens Japan (1853 CE)
desc: US forces end Japanese isolation.
desc_long: Commodore Perry's arrival forced Japan to end 220 years of isolation and begin modernization.

title: Crimean War (1853-1856 CE)
desc: Major conflict over Ottoman decline.
desc_long: Russia fought Britain, France, and Ottoman Empire in first modern war featuring trench warfare and nursing care.

title: Darwin's Origin of Species (1859 CE)
desc: Theory of evolution by natural selection published.
desc_long: Charles Darwin's revolutionary work transformed biology and our understanding of life's diversity.

title: Unification of Italy (1861 CE)
desc: Italian states unite into single kingdom.
desc_long: Risorgimento movement achieved unification under Victor Emmanuel II, creating modern Italy.

title: World War I Begins (1914 CE)
desc: Assassination triggers global conflict.
desc_long: Archduke Franz Ferdinand's assassination sparked the Great War, killing 20 million people.

title: Russian Revolution (1917 CE)
desc: Bolsheviks overthrow Tsar, establish communism.
desc_long: Lenin's revolution ended the Romanov dynasty and created the world's first communist state.

title: Spanish Flu Pandemic (1918 CE)
desc: Influenza kills 50 million worldwide.
desc_long: The deadliest pandemic in modern history infected 500 million people, one-third of world population.

title: Treaty of Versailles (1919 CE)
desc: WWI peace treaty reshapes Europe.
desc_long: Peace settlement imposed harsh terms on Germany, setting stage for World War II.

title: Tutankhamun's Tomb Discovered (1922 CE)
desc: Howard Carter finds intact pharaoh tomb.
desc_long: Discovery of the boy king's treasure-filled tomb captivated the world and advanced Egyptology.

title: Great Depression Begins (1929 CE)
desc: Stock market crash triggers global crisis.
desc_long: Wall Street Crash of 1929 began worldwide economic depression lasting through the 1930s.

title: Hitler Becomes Chancellor (1933 CE)
desc: Nazi party takes control of Germany.
desc_long: Adolf Hitler's appointment as Chancellor marked the beginning of Nazi dictatorship and path to war.

title: The Long March (1934-1935 CE)
desc: Chinese Communists escape Nationalist forces.
desc_long: Mao Zedong led Communist retreat across 6,000 miles, establishing him as revolutionary leader.

title: Hindenburg Disaster (1937 CE)
desc: Airship explodes, ending passenger zeppelin era.
desc_long: German passenger airship caught fire while landing, killing 36 and ending the airship age.

title: Invasion of Poland (1939 CE)
desc: Nazi invasion triggers World War II.
desc_long: German blitzkrieg on Poland began the deadliest conflict in human history.

title: Battle of Britain (1940 CE)
desc: RAF defends Britain from Luftwaffe.
desc_long: British victory in this air campaign prevented Nazi invasion and marked turning point in WWII.

title: Attack on Pearl Harbor (1941 CE)
desc: Japanese attack brings US into WWII.
desc_long: Surprise attack on US naval base brought America into World War II, changing the war's course.

title: Battle of Stalingrad (1942-1943 CE)
desc: Turning point on Eastern Front.
desc_long: Brutal battle destroyed German 6th Army and marked the beginning of Nazi retreat from Russia.

title: D-Day Normandy Invasion (1944 CE)
desc: Allied forces land in Nazi-occupied France.
desc_long: Largest amphibious invasion in history began the liberation of Western Europe from Nazi control.

title: Atomic Bomb Dropped on Hiroshima (1945 CE)
desc: First nuclear weapon used in warfare.
desc_long: US atomic bomb instantly killed 70,000 people, beginning the nuclear age and hastening WWII's end.

title: United Nations Founded (1945 CE)
desc: International organization established for peace.
desc_long: 51 nations created the UN to prevent future wars and promote international cooperation.

title: Partition of India (1947 CE)
desc: British India divided into India and Pakistan.
desc_long: Independence and partition caused mass migration and violence, killing up to 2 million people.

title: State of Israel Founded (1948 CE)
desc: Jewish state established, Arab-Israeli conflict begins.
desc_long: Declaration of Israeli independence led to immediate war and ongoing Middle East conflict.

title: Berlin Airlift (1948-1949 CE)
desc: Western Allies supply blockaded West Berlin.
desc_long: Response to Soviet blockade demonstrated Western resolve and marked an early Cold War crisis.

title: NATO Founded (1949 CE)
desc: Military alliance against Soviet expansion.
desc_long: North Atlantic Treaty Organization established collective defense against communist threat.

title: People's Republic of China Proclaimed (1949 CE)
desc: Mao establishes communist China.
desc_long: Communist victory in civil war created world's most populous communist state under Mao Zedong.

title: Korean War Begins (1950 CE)
desc: North invades South, Cold War turns hot.
desc_long: First major armed conflict of the Cold War resulted in permanent division of Korea.

title: Rosenbergs Executed (1953 CE)
desc: Spies executed in height of Red Scare.
desc_long: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg executed for espionage, symbolizing Cold War paranoia and nuclear fears.

title: Stalin Dies (1953 CE)
desc: Soviet dictator's death ends era of terror.
desc_long: Death of Joseph Stalin after 30 years of brutal rule opened possibility for de-Stalinization.

title: Brown v. Board of Education (1954 CE)
desc: Supreme Court outlaws school segregation.
desc_long: Landmark decision declared racial segregation in schools unconstitutional, advancing civil rights.

title: Warsaw Pact Formed (1955 CE)
desc: Soviet military alliance counters NATO.
desc_long: Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation and Mutual Assistance formalized Eastern Bloc military alliance.

title: Suez Crisis (1956 CE)
desc: Britain and France invade Egypt.
desc_long: Failed invasion exposed decline of European colonial powers and rise of US-Soviet dominance.

title: Hungarian Revolution (1956 CE)
desc: Uprising crushed by Soviet tanks.
desc_long: National revolt against Soviet control brutally suppressed, showing limits of resistance in Eastern Bloc.

title: Sputnik Launched (1957 CE)
desc: First artificial satellite begins Space Race.
desc_long: Soviet satellite shocked the West and initiated the space age and technological competition.

title: Cuban Revolution (1959 CE)
desc: Castro overthrows Batista dictatorship.
desc_long: Fidel Castro's revolution established communist government 90 miles from US, intensifying Cold War.

title: Berlin Wall Constructed (1961 CE)
desc: Concrete barrier divides East and West Berlin.
desc_long: Symbol of Cold War division, the wall prevented East Germans from fleeing to the West for 28 years.

title: Bay of Pigs Invasion (1961 CE)
desc: Failed US-backed invasion of Cuba.
desc_long: CIA-sponsored attempt to overthrow Castro ended in disaster, embarrassing the Kennedy administration.

title: Cuban Missile Crisis (1962 CE)
desc: World comes closest to nuclear war.
desc_long: 13-day confrontation over Soviet missiles in Cuba brought superpowers to brink of nuclear war.

title: JFK Assassination (1963 CE)
desc: President Kennedy murdered in Dallas.
desc_long: Assassination of President John F. Kennedy shocked the nation and sparked decades of conspiracy theories.

title: MLK 'I Have a Dream' Speech (1963 CE)
desc: King's speech at March on Washington.
desc_long: Martin Luther King Jr.'s powerful speech became defining moment of American civil rights movement.

title: Vietnam War Escalates (1965 CE)
desc: US commits ground troops to Vietnam.
desc_long: Major escalation of American involvement began decade-long conflict that divided the nation.

title: Cultural Revolution Begins (1966 CE)
desc: Mao launches radical social campaign.
desc_long: Decade of political upheaval and persecution caused deaths of millions and destroyed Chinese culture.

title: Six-Day War (1967 CE)
desc: Israel defeats Arab coalition decisively.
desc_long: Israel's lightning victory tripled its territory and reshaped Middle Eastern geopolitics.

title: Prague Spring (1968 CE)
desc: Czech reforms crushed by Soviet invasion.
desc_long: Brief period of liberalization ended when Warsaw Pact tanks rolled in to restore orthodoxy.

title: Apollo 11 Moon Landing (1969 CE)
desc: Humans walk on the Moon for first time.
desc_long: Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin fulfilled Kennedy's promise and won the Space Race for America.

title: Great Pyramid of Giza Built (2560 BCE)
desc: Construction of the largest pyramid in Egypt.
desc_long: The Great Pyramid of Giza, built for Pharaoh Khufu, is the oldest and largest of the three pyramids in the Giza pyramid complex. It remained the tallest man-made structure for over 3,800 years.

title: Fall of Troy (1180 BCE)
desc: Destruction of the legendary city of Troy.
desc_long: The fall of Troy, immortalized in Homer's Iliad, marked the end of the Trojan War. According to legend, the Greeks used the famous Trojan Horse to infiltrate and conquer the city.

title: Founding of Rome (753 BCE)
desc: Legendary foundation of Rome by Romulus.
desc_long: According to Roman mythology, Rome was founded by Romulus and Remus on April 21, 753 BCE. This event marked the beginning of Roman civilization that would dominate the Mediterranean world.

title: Battle of Marathon (490 BCE)
desc: Athenian victory over Persian invasion.
desc_long: The Battle of Marathon was a pivotal victory for Athens against the first Persian invasion of Greece. The Greek hoplites defeated a numerically superior Persian force, preserving Greek independence.

title: Battle of Thermopylae (480 BCE)
desc: 300 Spartans' legendary last stand.
desc_long: King Leonidas and 300 Spartans, along with other Greek forces, held the narrow pass of Thermopylae against the massive Persian army for three days before being outflanked and killed to the last man.

title: Battle of Salamis (480 BCE)
desc: Decisive Greek naval victory over Persia.
desc_long: The Battle of Salamis was a decisive naval battle where the Greek fleet under Themistocles defeated the much larger Persian navy, turning the tide of the Greco-Persian Wars.

title: Peloponnesian War Begins (431 BCE)
desc: War between Athens and Sparta begins.
desc_long: The Peloponnesian War was a prolonged conflict between the Athenian empire and the Peloponnesian League led by Sparta. The war reshaped the Greek world and weakened the city-states.

title: Death of Socrates (399 BCE)
desc: Philosopher Socrates executed by hemlock.
desc_long: Socrates was sentenced to death by drinking hemlock after being found guilty of impiety and corrupting the youth of Athens. His death became a symbol of the conflict between philosophy and authority.

title: Battle of Gaugamela (331 BCE)
desc: Alexander defeats Persian King Darius III.
desc_long: The Battle of Gaugamela was a decisive victory for Alexander the Great over the Persian Empire. Despite being heavily outnumbered, Alexander's tactics crushed Darius III's forces, opening the way to conquer Persia.

title: Founding of Alexandria (331 BCE)
desc: Alexander founds his greatest city.
desc_long: Alexandria was founded by Alexander the Great and became one of the most important cultural and intellectual centers of the ancient world, home to the famous Library of Alexandria.

title: Battle of Cannae (216 BCE)
desc: Hannibal's greatest tactical victory.
desc_long: The Battle of Cannae was one of the greatest military victories in history. Hannibal's Carthaginian forces encircled and destroyed a much larger Roman army, killing up to 70,000 Romans in a single day.

title: Assassination of Julius Caesar (44 BCE)
desc: Roman dictator killed by senators.
desc_long: Julius Caesar was assassinated by a group of senators on the Ides of March (March 15) in 44 BCE. His death led to civil war and the end of the Roman Republic, paving the way for the Roman Empire.

title: Birth of Jesus Christ (1 CE)
desc: Birth of Christianity's central figure.
desc_long: The birth of Jesus of Nazareth in Bethlehem marks the beginning of Christianity. His teachings and crucifixion would profoundly shape Western civilization and world religion.

title: Battle of Teutoburg Forest (9 CE)
desc: Germanic tribes annihilate Roman legions.
desc_long: The Battle of Teutoburg Forest was a devastating defeat for Rome. Germanic tribes led by Arminius ambushed and destroyed three Roman legions, halting Roman expansion into Germania.

title: Great Fire of Rome (64 CE)
desc: Massive fire devastates Rome.
desc_long: The Great Fire of Rome burned for six days, destroying much of the city. Emperor Nero was rumored to have started the fire, though he blamed Christians, leading to their persecution.

title: Destruction of Jerusalem (70 CE)
desc: Romans destroy Jerusalem and the Second Temple.
desc_long: The Siege of Jerusalem ended with the complete destruction of the city and the Second Temple by Roman forces under Titus. This event marked a turning point in Jewish history and diaspora.

title: Edict of Milan (313 CE)
desc: Constantine legalizes Christianity.
desc_long: The Edict of Milan was a proclamation that permanently established religious toleration for Christianity within the Roman Empire. It marked a turning point in the history of Christianity and the Roman Empire.

title: Council of Nicaea (325 CE)
desc: First ecumenical council of Christianity.
desc_long: The First Council of Nicaea was convened by Emperor Constantine to address the Arian controversy and establish key Christian doctrines, including the Nicene Creed.

title: Fall of Western Roman Empire (476 CE)
desc: Last Western Roman Emperor deposed.
desc_long: The deposition of Romulus Augustulus by Odoacer marked the end of the Western Roman Empire. This event is traditionally considered the end of antiquity and the beginning of the Middle Ages.

title: Justinian Plague (541 CE)
desc: First recorded pandemic of bubonic plague.
desc_long: The Plague of Justinian was the first recorded pandemic of bubonic plague, killing an estimated 25-50 million people across the Byzantine Empire and beyond, profoundly weakening the empire.

title: Battle of Marathon (490 BC)
desc: Decisive Athenian victory over Persian invasion.
desc_long: The Battle of Marathon was a watershed moment in Greek history where heavily outnumbered Athenian forces defeated the first Persian invasion, preserving Greek independence.

title: Battle of Salamis (480 BC)
desc: Naval battle where Greeks defeated Persian fleet.
desc_long: The naval Battle of Salamis was a decisive Greek victory that turned the tide of the Persian Wars and secured Western civilization's future.

title: Peloponnesian War (431-404 BC)
desc: Devastating war between Athens and Sparta.
desc_long: The Peloponnesian War between Athens and Sparta reshaped the Greek world, ending Athenian dominance and leading to Spartan hegemony.

title: Alexander's Conquests (334-323 BC)
desc: Alexander the Great's empire-building campaigns.
desc_long: Alexander the Great conquered the Persian Empire and reached India, creating one of history's largest empires and spreading Hellenistic culture.

title: Siege of Tyre (332 BC)
desc: Alexander's seven-month siege of island fortress.
desc_long: Alexander the Great's innovative siege of the island city of Tyre showcased advanced military engineering by building a causeway to the city.

title: Wars of the Diadochi (323-281 BC)
desc: Succession wars after Alexander's death.
desc_long: The Wars of the Diadochi divided Alexander's empire among his generals, establishing the Hellenistic kingdoms.

title: First Punic War (264-241 BC)
desc: Rome vs Carthage for control of Sicily.
desc_long: The First Punic War established Rome as a major naval power and began Rome's expansion beyond the Italian peninsula.

title: Gallic Wars (58-50 BC)
desc: Julius Caesar's conquest of Gaul.
desc_long: Caesar's military campaigns in Gaul extended Roman control to the Atlantic and Rhine, while his political power grew dramatically.

title: Battle of Alesia (52 BC)
desc: Caesar's decisive victory over Vercingetorix.
desc_long: The siege and battle of Alesia ended major Gallic resistance and secured Roman control of Gaul for centuries.

title: Assassination of Julius Caesar (44 BC)
desc: Caesar murdered by Roman senators.
desc_long: Julius Caesar's assassination on the Ides of March triggered civil wars that ended the Roman Republic and led to the Empire.

title: Caesar's Civil War (49-45 BC)
desc: Civil war between Caesar and Pompey.
desc_long: Caesar's crossing of the Rubicon sparked a civil war that ended the Roman Republic's oligarchic system.

title: Battle of Pharsalus (48 BC)
desc: Caesar's decisive victory over Pompey.
desc_long: The Battle of Pharsalus was the decisive engagement of Caesar's Civil War, securing his position as Rome's dominant leader.

title: Antonine Plague (165-180)
desc: Devastating pandemic in Roman Empire.
desc_long: The Antonine Plague, possibly smallpox, killed millions across the Roman Empire and weakened its military strength.

title: Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
desc: Period of Roman imperial instability.
desc_long: The Crisis of the Third Century nearly destroyed the Roman Empire through civil wars, invasions, and economic collapse.

title: Eruption of Thera (1600 BC)
desc: Massive volcanic eruption destroyed Minoan civilization.
desc_long: The Thera eruption was one of the largest volcanic events in recorded history, possibly inspiring the Atlantis legend.

title: Fall of Troy (1180 BC)
desc: Legendary siege and destruction of Troy.
desc_long: The Trojan War, immortalized in Homer's Iliad, marked the end of the Bronze Age and the city of Troy.

title: Bronze Age Collapse (1200 BC)
desc: Widespread societal collapse in Mediterranean.
desc_long: The Late Bronze Age collapse saw the fall of major civilizations including the Mycenaeans, Hittites, and others.

title: Battle of Kadesh (1274 BC)
desc: Epic battle between Egypt and Hittites.
desc_long: The Battle of Kadesh between Ramesses II and the Hittites was one of the largest chariot battles ever fought.

title: Exodus from Egypt (1450 BC)
desc: Biblical departure of Israelites from Egypt.
desc_long: The Exodus is the foundational narrative of the Israelites' liberation from slavery in ancient Egypt.

title: Great Pyramid Built (2560 BC)
desc: Construction of Great Pyramid of Giza.
desc_long: The Great Pyramid of Khufu is the oldest and largest of the three pyramids and remained the world's tallest structure for millennia.

title: Akkadian Empire Founded (2334 BC)
desc: Sargon creates first empire in history.
desc_long: Sargon of Akkad created the world's first multi-ethnic empire, uniting Mesopotamian city-states.

title: Fall of Ur (2004 BC)
desc: Destruction of Sumerian city of Ur.
desc_long: The fall of Ur marked the end of Sumerian political power in Mesopotamia.

title: Reign of Hammurabi (1792-1750 BC)
desc: Babylonian king establishes famous law code.
desc_long: Hammurabi united Mesopotamia and created one of history's first written law codes.

title: Hyksos Invasion of Egypt (1650 BC)
desc: Foreign rulers conquer Lower Egypt.
desc_long: The Hyksos introduced new military technology including the horse and chariot to Egypt.

title: Neo-Assyrian Empire Peak (700 BC)
desc: Assyria becomes dominant Middle Eastern power.
desc_long: The Neo-Assyrian Empire was the largest empire the world had seen, known for advanced military tactics and brutal conquests.

title: Sack of Nineveh (612 BC)
desc: Fall of Assyrian capital ends empire.
desc_long: The destruction of Nineveh by Babylonians and Medes ended Assyrian dominance in the ancient Near East.

title: Nebuchadnezzar's Reign (605-562 BC)
desc: Neo-Babylonian Empire reaches its peak.
desc_long: Nebuchadnezzar II built the Hanging Gardens and destroyed Jerusalem, taking Jews into Babylonian captivity.

title: Persian Conquest of Babylon (539 BC)
desc: Cyrus the Great captures Babylon.
desc_long: Cyrus the Great's conquest of Babylon ended the Neo-Babylonian Empire and established Persian dominance.

title: Sack of Jerusalem (586 BC)
desc: Babylonians destroy First Temple.
desc_long: Nebuchadnezzar's forces destroyed Solomon's Temple and began the Babylonian exile of the Jewish people.

title: Battle of Leuctra (371 BC)
desc: Theban victory ends Spartan hegemony.
desc_long: The Battle of Leuctra broke Sparta's military dominance in Greece through innovative tactics by Epaminondas.

title: Battle of Adrianople (378)
desc: Goths defeat Roman Emperor Valens.
desc_long: The Gothic victory at Adrianople marked a turning point in Roman military decline and the beginning of barbarian dominance.

title: Fall of Western Roman Empire (476)
desc: Last Western Roman Emperor deposed.
desc_long: The deposition of Romulus Augustulus marked the traditional end of the Western Roman Empire and the beginning of the Middle Ages.

title: Battle of Tours (732)
desc: Franks halt Muslim expansion into Europe.
desc_long: Charles Martel's victory at Tours stopped the Umayyad advance into Western Europe and preserved Christian control.

title: Charlemagne Crowned Emperor (800)
desc: Revival of Roman Empire in the West.
desc_long: Pope Leo III crowned Charlemagne as Holy Roman Emperor, establishing a new Western European political order.

title: Viking Raid on Lindisfarne (793)
desc: First major Viking raid marks Viking Age.
desc_long: The attack on Lindisfarne monastery shocked Christian Europe and began the era of Viking raids.

title: Treaty of Verdun (843)
desc: Division of Carolingian Empire.
desc_long: The Treaty of Verdun divided Charlemagne's empire among his grandsons, creating the basis for modern France and Germany.

title: Foundation of Kievan Rus (882)
desc: Viking prince Oleg unites East Slavic tribes.
desc_long: The foundation of Kievan Rus by Oleg established the first East Slavic state, ancestor to Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus.

title: Umayyad Caliphate (661-750)
desc: Islamic empire at its greatest extent.
desc_long: The Umayyad Caliphate expanded Islamic rule from Spain to Central Asia, creating one of history's largest empires.

title: Abbasid Revolution (750)
desc: Abbasids overthrow Umayyad dynasty.
desc_long: The Abbasid Revolution moved the caliphate's center to Baghdad and ushered in an Islamic Golden Age.

title: Battle of Manzikert (1071)
desc: Seljuk Turks defeat Byzantine Empire.
desc_long: The Seljuk victory opened Anatolia to Turkish settlement and weakened Byzantine power permanently.

title: Foundation of Cairo (969)
desc: Fatimid dynasty establishes new capital.
desc_long: The Fatimids founded Cairo as their capital, which became a major center of Islamic learning and culture.

title: Great Schism (1054)
desc: Split between Eastern and Western Christianity.
desc_long: The Great Schism divided Christianity into Catholic and Orthodox branches, a split that persists today.

title: Norman Conquest of England (1066)
desc: William the Conqueror invades England.
desc_long: The Norman Conquest transformed English society, language, and governance after William's victory at Hastings.

title: Buyid Conquest of Baghdad (945)
desc: Shia Buyids control Abbasid capital.
desc_long: The Buyid takeover reduced the Abbasid Caliphate to a figurehead while Shia warlords held real power.

title: Battle of Talas (751)
desc: Arab victory ends Tang expansion westward.
desc_long: The Battle of Talas established the boundary between Islamic and Chinese civilizations and introduced papermaking to the West.

title: An Lushan Rebellion (755-763)
desc: Devastating rebellion in Tang China.
desc_long: The An Lushan Rebellion was one of history's deadliest wars, killing millions and permanently weakening the Tang Dynasty.

title: Viking Siege of Paris (885-886)
desc: Vikings besiege Frankish capital.
desc_long: The successful defense of Paris against Viking raiders enhanced Frankish military prestige.

title: Christianization of Kievan Rus (988)
desc: Vladimir I adopts Orthodox Christianity.
desc_long: Prince Vladimir's conversion brought Kievan Rus into the Byzantine cultural sphere and established Orthodox Christianity in Eastern Europe.

title: Battle of Hastings (1066)
desc: Norman victory over Anglo-Saxons.
desc_long: William the Conqueror's victory at Hastings fundamentally changed English society, language, and governance.

title: Battle of Stirling Bridge (1297)
desc: William Wallace defeats English army.
desc_long: Wallace's tactical victory was a major triumph in the Scottish Wars of Independence.

title: Fourth Crusade (1202-1204)
desc: Crusaders sack Constantinople.
desc_long: The Fourth Crusade diverted to Constantinople, sacking the Christian city and fatally weakening the Byzantine Empire.

title: Battle of Ain Jalut (1260)
desc: Mamluks halt Mongol expansion.
desc_long: The Mamluk victory at Ain Jalut was the first major defeat of the Mongols and saved the Islamic Middle East.

title: Mongol Sack of Baghdad (1258)
desc: Mongols destroy Abbasid capital.
desc_long: Hulagu Khan's destruction of Baghdad ended the Islamic Golden Age and killed hundreds of thousands.

title: Battle of Bosworth Field (1485)
desc: Henry Tudor defeats Richard III.
desc_long: Bosworth Field ended the Wars of the Roses and began the Tudor dynasty that would transform England.

title: Battle of Agincourt (1415)
desc: English longbowmen defeat French knights.
desc_long: Henry V's outnumbered army won a legendary victory demonstrating the power of English longbows.

title: Fall of Granada (1492)
desc: Christian reconquest of Spain completed.
desc_long: The fall of Granada ended 781 years of Muslim rule in Iberia and completed the Reconquista.

title: Battle of Grunwald (1410)
desc: Polish-Lithuanian victory over Teutonic Knights.
desc_long: One of medieval Europe's largest battles decisively defeated the Teutonic Order.

title: Battle of Kosovo (1389)
desc: Ottoman victory over Serbian-led coalition.
desc_long: The Battle of Kosovo marked the beginning of Ottoman domination in the Balkans.

title: Fall of Constantinople (1453)
desc: Ottoman conquest ends Byzantine Empire.
desc_long: Mehmed II's conquest of Constantinople ended the thousand-year Byzantine Empire and marked the end of the Middle Ages.

title: Black Death (1347-1353)
desc: Bubonic plague devastates Europe.
desc_long: The Black Death killed 30-60% of Europe's population, fundamentally transforming European society and economy.

title: Great Famine (1315-1317)
desc: Catastrophic crop failures across Europe.
desc_long: The Great Famine killed millions in Northern Europe due to extreme weather and crop failures.

title: Jacquerie Uprising (1358)
desc: Violent peasant revolt in France.
desc_long: The Jacquerie was a brutal peasant revolt against nobility during the Hundred Years' War.

title: Battle of Nicopolis (1396)
desc: Ottoman victory over Crusader army.
desc_long: The 'Crusade of Nicopolis' ended in disaster, confirming Ottoman dominance in the Balkans.

title: Gutenberg Printing Press (1450)
desc: Revolutionary movable type printing invented.
desc_long: Gutenberg's invention revolutionized information distribution and enabled the Renaissance and Reformation.

title: Battle of Varna (1444)
desc: Ottoman victory crushes Crusade of Varna.
desc_long: The Ottoman victory at Varna ended the last major crusading effort to halt Turkish expansion.

title: End of Hundred Years' War (1453)
desc: French victory ends English continental holdings.
desc_long: The Battle of Castillon ended the Hundred Years' War with French victory and English expulsion from France.

title: Columbus Reaches America (1492)
desc: European discovery of the Americas.
desc_long: Columbus's voyage initiated European colonization of the Americas and the Columbian Exchange.

title: Luther's 95 Theses (1517)
desc: Beginning of Protestant Reformation.
desc_long: Martin Luther's challenge to Catholic practices sparked the Protestant Reformation that divided Western Christianity.

title: Spanish Conquest of Aztec Empire (1521)
desc: Cortés conquers Tenochtitlan.
desc_long: Hernán Cortés's conquest of the Aztec Empire marked a decisive moment in European colonization of the Americas.

title: Battle of Pavia (1525)
desc: Habsburg victory captures French king.
desc_long: The capture of Francis I at Pavia established Habsburg dominance in Italy.

title: Sack of Rome (1527)
desc: Imperial troops devastate papal Rome.
desc_long: The brutal sack of Rome by Habsburg forces marked a symbolic end to the Italian Renaissance.

title: Spanish Conquest of Inca Empire (1533)
desc: Pizarro conquers Inca civilization.
desc_long: Francisco Pizarro's conquest ended the Inca Empire, the largest pre-Columbian state in the Americas.

title: Copernican Revolution (1543)
desc: Heliocentric model published.
desc_long: Copernicus's theory that Earth orbits the Sun revolutionized astronomy and challenged religious doctrine.

title: Council of Trent (1545-1563)
desc: Catholic Counter-Reformation begins.
desc_long: The Council of Trent reformed Catholic practices and doctrine in response to the Protestant Reformation.

title: Battle of Lepanto (1571)
desc: Christian fleet defeats Ottoman navy.
desc_long: The Holy League's naval victory at Lepanto halted Ottoman expansion in the Mediterranean.

title: St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre (1572)
desc: Mass killing of French Huguenots.
desc_long: Catholic mobs killed thousands of Protestant Huguenots in Paris during the French Wars of Religion.

title: Spanish Armada Defeated (1588)
desc: English defeat Spanish invasion fleet.
desc_long: The defeat of the Spanish Armada established England as a major naval power and began Spain's decline.

title: Edict of Nantes (1598)
desc: Religious tolerance granted to Huguenots.
desc_long: Henry IV's edict granted Protestants religious freedom and ended the French Wars of Religion.

title: Shakespeare First Folio (1623)
desc: First collected edition of Shakespeare's plays.
desc_long: The First Folio preserved Shakespeare's plays for posterity, cementing his place as the greatest English writer.

title: Thirty Years' War (1618-1648)
desc: Devastating religious war in Europe.
desc_long: The Thirty Years' War devastated Central Europe, killing millions and establishing the modern state system.

title: English Civil War (1642-1651)
desc: Parliamentarians vs Royalists.
desc_long: The English Civil War resulted in the execution of Charles I and temporary abolition of the monarchy.

title: Peace of Westphalia (1648)
desc: Treaties ending Thirty Years' War.
desc_long: The Peace of Westphalia established principles of state sovereignty that still underpin international relations.

title: Execution of Charles I (1649)
desc: English king beheaded by Parliament.
desc_long: Charles I's execution shocked Europe and established the English Commonwealth under Oliver Cromwell.

title: Great Fire of London (1666)
desc: Massive fire destroys much of London.
desc_long: The Great Fire destroyed 13,000 houses and 87 churches, leading to London's reconstruction with improved fire safety.

title: Glorious Revolution (1688)
desc: William III replaces James II bloodlessly.
desc_long: The Glorious Revolution established parliamentary supremacy and constitutional monarchy in England.

title: Newton's Principia Published (1687)
desc: Laws of motion and universal gravitation.
desc_long: Newton's Principia Mathematica laid the foundation for classical mechanics and the Scientific Revolution.

title: Great Northern War (1700-1721)
desc: Russia emerges as European great power.
desc_long: Peter the Great's victory over Sweden established Russia as a major European power and founded St. Petersburg.

title: War of Spanish Succession (1701-1714)
desc: European powers contest Spanish throne.
desc_long: This major European conflict established the balance of power system and gave Britain Gibraltar.

title: Battle of Poltava (1709)
desc: Russia defeats Sweden decisively.
desc_long: Peter the Great's victory ended Swedish dominance in Northern Europe and established Russian power.

title: Treaty of Utrecht (1713)
desc: Peace settlement ends major European war.
desc_long: The Treaty of Utrecht reshaped Europe's political map and gave Britain significant colonial gains.

title: War of Austrian Succession (1740-1748)
desc: European powers contest Habsburg succession.
desc_long: This conflict confirmed Maria Theresa's rule and Prussia's status as a great power.

title: Seven Years' War (1756-1763)
desc: First global war involving major powers.
desc_long: Often called the first true world war, it established British colonial dominance and Prussian power.

title: Battle of Plassey (1757)
desc: British East India Company conquers Bengal.
desc_long: Robert Clive's victory established British control in India and began two centuries of colonial rule.

title: Battle of Quebec (1759)
desc: British capture Quebec from France.
desc_long: Wolfe's victory at Quebec secured British control of Canada and North America.

title: Lisbon Earthquake (1755)
desc: Devastating earthquake and tsunami.
desc_long: One of history's deadliest earthquakes destroyed Lisbon and sparked philosophical debates about divine providence.

title: American Revolution (1775-1783)
desc: Thirteen colonies win independence.
desc_long: The American Revolution established the United States and inspired democratic movements worldwide.

title: Declaration of Independence (1776)
desc: American colonies declare independence.
desc_long: Jefferson's declaration articulated principles of natural rights and self-governance that inspired revolutions globally.

title: Battle of Yorktown (1781)
desc: Decisive American victory ends Revolution.
desc_long: Cornwallis's surrender at Yorktown effectively ended the Revolutionary War and secured American independence.

title: French Revolution Begins (1789)
desc: Storming of Bastille starts revolution.
desc_long: The French Revolution overthrew the monarchy and transformed European politics with ideals of liberty, equality, and fraternity.

title: U.S. Constitution Ratified (1787)
desc: Foundation of American government.
desc_long: The U.S. Constitution established the world's oldest continuous democratic republic.

title: Reign of Terror (1793-1794)
desc: Mass executions during French Revolution.
desc_long: The Reign of Terror saw thousands guillotined as revolutionary leaders eliminated perceived enemies.

title: Haitian Revolution (1791-1804)
desc: Successful slave revolt establishes Haiti.
desc_long: The only successful slave revolution in history created the first Black republic and second independent nation in the Americas.

title: Battle of Trafalgar (1805)
desc: Nelson defeats Franco-Spanish fleet.
desc_long: Nelson's victory at Trafalgar secured British naval supremacy for a century but cost the admiral his life.

title: Battle of Austerlitz (1805)
desc: Napoleon's greatest victory.
desc_long: The 'Battle of the Three Emperors' was Napoleon's most brilliant tactical triumph, crushing Austrian and Russian armies.

title: Latin American Independence Wars (1808-1826)
desc: Spanish colonies gain independence.
desc_long: Revolutionary movements led by Bolivar and San Martin freed most of South America from Spanish rule.

title: Napoleon's Invasion of Russia (1812)
desc: Disastrous campaign destroys Grande Armée.
desc_long: Napoleon's failed Russian campaign destroyed his army and began his downfall, with winter and scorched earth tactics devastating French forces.

title: War of 1812 (1812-1815)
desc: US-British conflict over trade and territory.
desc_long: The War of 1812 confirmed American independence and led to an era of good feelings in US politics.

title: Battle of Leipzig (1813)
desc: Largest battle before WWI defeats Napoleon.
desc_long: The 'Battle of Nations' involved 500,000 troops and decisively defeated Napoleon, forcing his abdication.

title: Battle of Waterloo (1815)
desc: Wellington and Blücher defeat Napoleon.
desc_long: Napoleon's final defeat at Waterloo ended his rule and the Napoleonic Wars, reshaping European politics.

title: Congress of Vienna (1815)
desc: European powers redraw map after Napoleon.
desc_long: The Congress of Vienna established a balance of power system that maintained relative peace in Europe for decades.

title: Greek War of Independence (1821-1829)
desc: Greeks win independence from Ottomans.
desc_long: The Greek Revolution established modern Greece and inspired nationalist movements across Europe.

title: First Opium War (1839-1842)
desc: Britain forces China to open trade.
desc_long: British victory forced China to cede Hong Kong and opened Chinese ports, beginning the 'Century of Humiliation.'

title: Irish Potato Famine (1845-1852)
desc: Catastrophic famine kills millions.
desc_long: The Great Famine killed over a million Irish and forced another million to emigrate, reshaping Ireland forever.

title: Revolutions of 1848
desc: Wave of liberal revolutions across Europe.
desc_long: The 'Springtime of Nations' saw widespread revolutionary movements demanding democracy and national independence.

title: Crimean War (1853-1856)
desc: Coalition defeats Russia in Crimea.
desc_long: The Crimean War showcased modern military technology and exposed Russian weaknesses, prompting reforms.

title: Indian Rebellion of 1857
desc: Major uprising against British rule.
desc_long: The Sepoy Mutiny led to the end of East India Company rule and establishment of direct British colonial government.

title: Italian Unification (1861)
desc: Italy unified under Victor Emmanuel II.
desc_long: The Risorgimento united Italy's various states into a single nation under the House of Savoy.

title: American Civil War (1861-1865)
desc: Union defeats Confederacy, ends slavery.
desc_long: America's bloodiest war preserved the Union and abolished slavery but left lasting regional divisions.

title: Battle of Gettysburg (1863)
desc: Turning point of American Civil War.
desc_long: The Union victory at Gettysburg marked the war's turning point and inspired Lincoln's famous address.

title: Meiji Restoration (1868)
desc: Japan begins rapid modernization.
desc_long: The Meiji Restoration ended feudalism and transformed Japan into a modern industrial power.

title: German Unification (1871)
desc: Prussia unites Germany under Bismarck.
desc_long: Bismarck's wars unified Germany into a powerful empire that transformed European power dynamics.

title: Franco-Prussian War (1870-1871)
desc: Prussian victory leads to German Empire.
desc_long: Prussia's decisive victory unified Germany, humiliated France, and set the stage for future European conflicts.

title: Great Chicago Fire (1871)
desc: Devastating urban fire destroys Chicago.
desc_long: The Great Chicago Fire destroyed much of the city but led to innovative rebuilding and urban planning.

title: Third Anglo-Burmese War (1885)
desc: Britain annexes Upper Burma.
desc_long: The final Anglo-Burmese war ended Burmese independence and completed British control of Burma.

title: Johnstown Flood (1889)
desc: Dam failure kills thousands.
desc_long: The catastrophic dam failure at Johnstown killed over 2,200 people in one of America's worst disasters.

title: First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895)
desc: Japan defeats China decisively.
desc_long: Japan's victory demonstrated its modernization success and began China's descent into chaos.
